sn7.8:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn7.8:1.2: Now at that time ghee and milk-rice had been set out for the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper, who thought,
sn7.8:1.3: “I will serve the sacred flame! I will perform the fire sacrifice!”
sn7.8:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
sn7.8:2.2: Wandering indiscriminately for almsfood in Rājagaha, he approached Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper’s home and stood to one side.
sn7.8:2.3: Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper saw him standing for alms
sn7.8:3.1: “One who’s accomplished in the three knowledges,
sn7.8:3.2: of good birth and ample learning,
sn7.8:4.3: if they’re filthy and corrupt within,
sn7.8:4.4: with a following gained by fraud.
sn7.8:5.1: One who knows their past lives,
sn7.8:5.2: sees heaven and places of loss,
sn7.8:5.3: and has attained the ending of rebirth,
sn7.8:5.4: is a sage of perfect insight.
sn7.8:6.2: a brahmin is a master of the three knowledges.
sn7.8:7.2: The worthy one is a brahmin.”
sn7.8:8.1: “Food enchanted by a verse isn’t fit for me to eat.
sn7.8:8.2: That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin.
sn7.8:8.3: The Buddhas cast aside things enchanted with verses.
sn7.8:8.4: Since there is such a principle, brahmin, <j>that’s how they live.
sn7.8:9.1: Serve with other food and drink
sn7.8:9.2: the consummate one, the great seer,
sn7.8:9.3: with defilements ended and remorse stilled.
sn7.8:9.4: For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”
sn7.8:10.1: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper said to the Buddha,
sn7.8:10.3: And Venerable Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper became one of the perfected.
